response.answer_text: I have given up trying to explain why consciousness is not an emergent property and why emergence is incoherent when applied to consciousness, so this answer is only for readers who already understand that the eliminativist/materialist account of consciousness fails. This means that you understand that awareness cannot be something that physical objects do, or a quality that they have (panpsychism), or even that mind and matter are two parts of the same coin (dual aspect monism), but that all forms and functions, physical or logical, can only exist within a context of what might be called pansensitivity, or sensation-that-makes-sense. This is not to say that human consciousness is the center of the universe and that all phenomena must make sense to us, but that all phenomena must be present in some modality of detection and interaction. This can be understood rationally with no need of any empirical testing. All that is required is for us to play out the null hypothesis: If there is no possibility of any detection or interaction with phenomenon X, then phenomenon X is indiscernible from nothing at all. The OP then, asking how human consciousness works, should be broken down into two separate parts: 1) How does awareness in general work?2) How does human consciousness differ from awareness in general? 1) In consideration of the above, the 'how' of awareness becomes a metaphysical issue - it could be said even a meta-ontological issue. If awareness-in-general (or use my term pansensitivity) is the most primitive prerequisite for all phenomena in all possible universes, then we must retrain ourselves to stop looking for more primitive phenomena which compose awareness.  I think that we can say awareness is sensory-motive in nature. That is, there is a quality of passive perceiving and active participating which cannot be rationally done without. Even an atom or subatomic particle requires a context where its identity is made coherent in some way, where its presence is detected or can be inferred from some detection of its effects. In the absence of such a detection, again, there is no difference between such a particle and nothing at all. There is no context from which to derive that difference.  That doesn't mean solipsism - it doesn't mean that particles don't exist unless we see them, but it does mean that the concept of 'existence' is incompatible with the existence of our own consciousness unless it is identical to detection/participation in some modality or context.  We need not posit a universal mind or God (although there is nothing that I am proposing which rules that out), only that existence itself in the absence of all perception is fantastically implausible given that 100% of what we know of the universe comes to us exclusively through perception. If the universe doesn't need perception, then there would be no rational explanation for why some parts of the universe could evolve such a redundant and irrational feature to depend upon exclusively. From this sensory-motive awareness-in-general, we can develop a hypothesis about how it divides and multiplies itself into different perceived forms and participatory functions. This entails performing a kind of Copernican inversion on our early 21st century* worldview, turning the outside (<matter>mass>energy>entropy>space) in, and the inside (pansense>sense<motive>significance>time) out. I don't expect anyone to really understand that right away...it has taken me several years to put it together in those terms, but hopefully the general idea of the role that symmetry plays comes through. Suffice it to say, I think that how awareness works is that it plays with variations on itself using separation and reconnection on many levels at once. It's very much like the view that has been a part of Eastern philosophy and Western mysticism for centuries, but with the important difference of plugging directly into modern models of physics and information.  As far as information goes, the sensory-motive primitive can be plugged into the medium-signal relation. Physics gives us a lot of these kinds of conjugates: surface-depth, electro-magnetism, space-time, mass-energy, etc, but when we are working with information and semiotics, we lose the concrete reality of sensation and substitute automatic, ideal abstractions of theoretical mechanics. Computer science and math do not concern themselves with how one number is able to add itself to another, only that there is a reliable result. Physics does focus on how phenomena interact, but not what those interactions actually are or what it is that is actually doing the interacting. The Medium-Signal RelationIn a simple case of communication, two people might hold a string tight on opposite sides of a room and pull on the string once to indicate 'yes/true/1' and twice for 'no/false/0'. In this case the string pulling, along with the tactile sensitivity of each person to detect the state of the string with their hands would be the medium. We can argue that behind that sensitivity is a lot of other cellular and molecular interaction, but that only pushes the medium down into the microphysical level of description. Even at the bottom, we still need some quantum-atomic sensitivity for any kind of basis of interaction to emerge (or diverge). The combination of string pulling and any schema which is applied to the interpretation of those pulls would be the signal or sign. Many if not most people confuse 'signals' with the physical conditions (string pulling, neurons 'firing', semiconductors polarizing, etc), but a better understanding is that the signal is a semiotic interpretation; a conscious consideration of changing conditions within a sensory-motive medium. Another metaphor that I like is brightness vs contrast. Brightness is the medium - if you have zero brightness there is nothing to see. Light, brightness, and the ability to see are, in the absolute sense, the same thing: a condition of awareness. Contrast stands in here for information or signal, which is a second-order relation of brightness and darkness. If you have no brightness, contrast doesn't help, but if you do have brightness, then contrast allows many degrees of brightness and frequencies of its absorption to be presented simultaneously.  2) The difference between awareness in general and human consciousness is the incredible degree of elaboration, and the specific experiences which have shaped Homo sapiens. The degree of elaboration I'm referring to would be the number of steps from raw pansensitivity to particular subjective sense vs objectively distanced sense (matter-space), to organic molecules, to cells, to tissues, organs, animals, and vertebrates. The corresponding consciousness of such an elaborate chain of continuous world-crafting seems likely to be be appropriately rich and deep aesthetically. The base level sense and motive is enhanced by orders of magnitude to a heart wrenching, visceral level of participation. I propose that the specific experiences which have shaped us individually and as a species lend our human consciousness its particular qualities. We share many qualities with other species - perhaps tender emotions with mammals, coarse emotions with reptiles, playful trickery with primates, etc. It's all sourced in real experience over hundreds of millions of years. It is, in my view, very much like our individual psychology is shaped by our experience, and our families and societies are shaped by their histories. This is what makes human consciousness human, and this is why an AI cannot simulate who we are. A computer may copy the signals from the medium of our communications, or from the medium of neuroscience, but without the medium of the totality of human experience going all the way back to before the first life form, it will only be a kind of doll - an imitation of who we are cobbled together from what our brains are and how they behave.  *really legacy 20th century

It depends who you ask. If you ask a neuroscientist they would probably say that consciousness is generated by the brain. Brain activity, specifically the firing of neurons, is the phenomenon  most correlated with consciousness that we know. It seems clear to many neuroscientists that our experience of objects, thoughts and actions, the detailed structure of each of these, is identical to the sequential firing of various groups of neurons. This seems reasonable except for one aspect of experience; equally important to the structure and dynamics (what it is), is the fact that we have an experience of it all. The unique correlation of one phenomenon with another, in this case neural firing with the contents of consciousness, may indicate an identity, but it gives no explanation for the awareness of those contents. What I am talking about is the thing about the color red that you will never explain to a blind man, no matter how long you want to take. The subjective quality of consciousness is explained by neuroscience in terms of self reference. Each brain state, potential quale, must be presented to, or available to, (here the theory gets a bit fuzzy) some form or structure (presumably more neural activity) representing or instantiating the self and then... a miracle happens and there is awareness of the presented potential quale. Some scientists who aren't so keen on miracles realise that the dominant materialist explanation of consciousness can't come up with a better explanation than this, there will never be a way to explain the subjective nature of experience in terms of mechanism, neural firing, other than saying that they are identical. So what they say is that this subjective quality of experience is actually illusory, just something produced by the self-referent information processing of the brain, the neural firing correlated with the contents of consciousness (which as noted above gives no explanation of the nature of subjective experience). Essentially, you aren't really conscious, you just think you are. The problem with this theory (apart from the obvious), is two-fold: Firstly, the fact that awareness is possible without any phenomenal experience (ie. experience of objects or thoughts). Not only is representation (self or not) not necessary for awareness, but these experiences of pure awareness are actually the most intense and clear experiences of awareness possible. All phenomenal experience occurs within awareness but awareness can occur without the experience of discrete phenomena. Thus, awareness is not produced by the interactions of representations of these phenomena. Secondly, the theory is materialist in the sense that it assumes all phenomena are explained solely in terms of the dynamics of material components, discrete entities that exist in an external, independent  (of the subject) world of time and space. These entities of matter are what is real and the reality of subjective experience that may or may not be generated by them is up for debate. However, such a view of reality has been obsolete for nearly a century. We now know that the nature of matter as discrete particles is inextricably dependent on the experience, or observation, of those particles and their effects. If matter is not observed it has no material properties; no mass, no specific spatial location, no effect on any other matter. Instead what exists when unobserved is only an interacting superposition of possibilities, possible future experiences of particulate matter when it is observed. What characterizes a piece of matter, the essence of what it is, is nothing more than how it consistently interacts with other matter - it's properties. This relational definition leaves no room for intrinsically existing "stuff". The stuff is just inferred, inferred from ongoing consistent interactions between bits of stuff and between stuff and an observer. The interactions are real. The stuff and the observers are all inferred, with only a relative reality, defining each other in each experience, everything constrained to fit into a story about material objects whizzing around within the fundamental axiomatic dimensions of time and space. Instead they are only the fundamental axioms of our cognized experience.

It doesn't! :) I'm (half) joking. The reason I say that human consciousness doesn't "work" is because no one can define it in a scientific way, and further, we cannot say why it might be useful for humans and other animals. Philosophers have the concept of a philosophical zombie  — a being that looks and acts just like a normal human being, but doesn't have consciousness. How would anyone be able to tell from the outside? And if it is logically conceivable that such a being could exist, then perhaps consciousness isn't really doing any "work". Of course I am aware that the question is really about how consciousness arises from biological matter. Since we can't define consciousness scientifically, we are not really able to "pin it down" in a laboratory. So all we can really say is that consciousness somehow seems to emerge from neural activity, and that it has to do with subjective experience, self-awareness, attention, and the concept of  a mental space.  I would go so far as to say that no neuroscientist ever really studies 'consciousness' in the sense that the word is used by philosophers and the general public. What we study is objectively observable behavior: this includes cognition, attention, awareness, movement and perception. But none of these observables are synonymous with subjective consciousness. At best we make indirect inferences about subjective experience based on observations. And we link these inferences with neuroscience and philosophy to create speculative stories about consciousness. These stories are fun and I highly recommend playing around with them, but we have to realize that consciousness is one of those concepts that we may never have a handle on. Over the past few years I've answered a surprising number of questions about consciousness. Here are a few that might be illuminating:  What is the currently best scientific answer to the psycho-physical (body-mind) question?Does modern science know how human consciousness has developed?What is the evolutionary reason for having consciousness?Is consciousness computation or a dynamic pattern of "something" (energy, matter) flowing? (Some of my own speculation here!)What's the correlation between complexity and consciousness?How can we measure human consciousness?Is consciousness an illusion?Could you have two independent consciousness(es) if you split a brain in half?How can understanding consciousness and the brain change the future of humanity?Can consciousness be separated from body-awareness?

Quoting the last line in a Science article from late last year October 2017 “What is consciousness, and could machines have it?” Although centuries of philosophical dualism have led us to consider consciousness as unreducible to physical interactions, the empirical evidence is compatible with the possibility that consciousness arises from nothing more than specific computations. Perhaps the premise of the article, “could machines be conscious?” necessarily forces the examination of what is consciousness from a computational perspective, cleverly skirting the philosophical debate. While we are still quite far from answering “how human consciousness works ?” even from a computational perspective, the article throws some light on this question (again from a computational perspective) by breaking conscousness down into two types of information processing computations in order to highlight what is missing in current machines despite their successes (accuracy) in tasks involving perception, classification, and translation - tasks that were until recently beyond the reach of machines.Breaking human consciousness down into these two types of information processing also enables us to think of how they may inspire novel machine architectures that are conscious.From the perspective of machine learning community, however, which continues to draw inspiration from how our brains work, the approach so far is not to emulate these information processing systems but selectively choose certain aspects of conscious processing “as priors” into machine learning architecture.A recent example of that is the choice of a consciousness prior by Yoshua Bengio into existing machine learning models so they can hopefully perform causal reasoning and planning.So what are the two types of information processing computations that is collectively called consciousness? Global availability C1 (very closely related to attention) . This seems to be a boring coinage, but it captures a key notion of consciousness. Our brain is organized into specialized subsystems for efficient processing, but this also poses a challenge - it leads to a diversity of probabilistic interpretations. So the brain needs to choose among the various possibilities and decide on a single course of action.For example, a thirsty elephant needs to determine the location of the nearest water hole and move towards it. Such decision making requires an architecture for efficient pooling over all available sources of sensory information, choosing the best option, sticking to that option over time, and coordinating all internal and external processes towards the achievement of that goal. In summary integrating all available evidence to converge towards a goal, is faced by any animal or autonomous system and corresponds to the first definition of consciousness : global availabilityThis form of consciousness is present in humans and animals (to varying degrees)Self-monitoring C2. While C1 consciousness reflects capacity to access external information, self-monitoring is the ability to reflexively represent oneself. Error detection is an example of self-monitoring and even one year old infants know they made a wrong choice in perceptual decision tasks.These two types of information processing are largely considered complementary/orthogonal dimensions of consciousness.Any information processing in our brains that does not fall into these two categories falls into a third bucket/category C0 and is called unconscious processing. This category is where the bulk of our intelligence lies. Interestingly the processing done by all currently successful machine learning models fall into this category of information processing in the brain (needless to say that does not imply intelligence is largely emulated in machines).So it is the C1 and C2 types of processing that current machines lack and need to have in order to become conscious.The choice of incorporating a conscious prior into current models as proposed by Yoshua Bengio accomplishes in part the C1 deficiency of current machine learning models (though it does not address C2)Also, from a machine learning perspective, the representations of experiences gathered through sensory input are largely high dimensional distributed representations - all tasks performed by current machine learning models are on these representations. It remains to be seen what is the nature of those representations upon which unconscious processing operates on. A claim Yoshua makes in his work, is our conscious processing must be on low dimensional representations - such a constraint imposed facilitates the generation of a low dimensional representation assisted by an attention mechanism over the high dimensional distributed representation that serves as the substrate. It remains to be seen if there is such an analogue in our brains.We do have evidence that experiences are transferred from the hippocampus to the cortical areas during sleep, along with selective erasures of the hippocampus, presumably like a scratch pad being erased for future use. However it is not known if this consolidation of experiences into the cortical areas is an abstraction of the sensory experiences like the low dimensional representations being studied as candidates for reasoning and planning in machines. A Study of Consciousness Jamshed R Bilimoria Premise: Consciousness is the pure subject. It is the internal witness. It is our true self. This is because it looks ‘out’ to all our mental and sensory inputs.They are a part of the object. Yet, as we are aware from daily experience, consciousness is aware of itself. It is self evident. It does not need the intellect to know itself.In deep-sleep, where there is an absence of intellect, we are able to be aware of the ‘nothingness’ of deep-sleep. The basic flaw in todays Scientific thinking is clumping our mental faculties (thoughts in our brain) along with that which is aware/conscious of them, as one and the same entity. In fact, they are separate entities. Consciousness can experience thoughts as the object and therefore has to be different. As Consciousnesses origin is closer than our brain, all our attempts to capture it in the world, including other peoples or species consciousness, will be futile. We are looking at the wrong side of the telescope. The only way to ‘experience’ pure Consciousness is to look within. This is beyond Realism. That is why the hard problem is nowhere near solved. Scientist have to step aside. Because it is internal, it can only be known in its entirety by a logical process popularly known as Advaita Vedanta. It is a study, using the scientific temperament, of how to experience Nascent Consciousness. Witness: Your thoughts may be different from another but the experience of pure “I know’ is the same in all. It is the pure ‘aware-ing’ factor in all species. The equipment’s of perception-emotion-thought vary from species to species. The 3 states of consciousness- waking-dream-deep sleep, the 3 states of mind-conscious-sub conscious- unconscious are nothing but consciousness contacting different modes of mind. Identity: Consciousness is separate from the equipment’s and modes of mind. It is the pure awareness factor, the pure ‘I am’. I am aware-of the tree. I am aware-of love. I am aware-of this thought. The fact that perception-emotion-thought, waking-dream-deepsleep, conscious-sub conscious-unconscious, can be recognised as the ‘object’ of experience (you are aware of the darkness of the unconscious and deep sleep) indicates that the true ‘I am’ (Pure Consciousness) is you core. Your real Self. Absolute Objectivity: Your real Self is Consciousness and not this personality. The body/brain is matter/energy - temporary, ephemeral, finite, limited. What witnesses it is your real Self, Consciousness. It objectively, coldly, looks at time, space and matter through thought and perception. You can never die. Pure Consciousness can never die. Only matter/energy can change form (‘die’). Something cannot disappear into nothing. And something cannot come out of nothing. All energy is permanent. The first Law of Thermodynamics. Consciousness can also be termed pure Energy. Self: Consciousness is not matter/energy. Consciousness is not thought or brainwaves. It is the witness of the outcome of brainwaves. It watches the intellect, thought, feelings, impulses, and perceptions. Consciousness is the closest we can get to our Self. In fact, we can’t get any closer because it is the real subject. It is the first person in us. It looks out at everything. Everything else is exterior to it. Infinite: You think, who witnesses the thoughts? Who is aware of the thoughts? Conditioned Consciousness. Consciousness conditioned by the electro-chemistry of our brain. (It stands alone as primary awareness, Pure Consciousness. Our true nature.) Thoughts whiz by like a film. Who watches that film? Another thought! Then, you are guilty of infinite progression. To give yourself the benefit of doubt, at the end of the day, Consciousness is aware of even that infinite thought because it is the awareness principle in thought. The same can be said about all our other mental faculties—emotions, impulses, whims, fancies, dreams, fantasies, drives, passions. To emphasise, what is that entity which is aware of all the outcomes of the brains activities? It is the awareness principle per se. Pure Consciousness, pure awareness. The ‘I am’ that stands alone. ‘I am’ ‘thinking.’ ‘I am’ ‘sad.’ ‘I am’ ‘fretful.’ ‘I am’ ‘in love.’ At the level of perception, the same Consciousness works. The eyes see the colour and form of a flower. But without Consciousness to be aware of the colour and form, the flower would not be perceived. Similarly, you hear the sound of a symphony through your ears. But without pure Consciousness, the sound would not be heard. Fundamental: As soon as you see the flower, you say ‘I see a flower’ or ‘I am’ ‘seeing a flower’ or ‘I am’ ‘hearing a symphony.’ This Consciousness is what we unconsciously equate with ourselves all through our lives. ‘I think,’ ‘I feel,’ ‘I say,’ ‘I smell’ are all directly pointing at our Consciousness, though we may not be aware of it. We presume we are indicating our mind, but we are not. Awareness is aware of thought. Awareness is aware of feeling. Awareness is aware of speech. Awareness is aware of smell. It is the Eye of the eye. The Ear of the ear. Non-material: Pure Consciousness is subjective thought ad infinitum - “I know” “I know that I know” “I know that I know that I know”……….Pure Consciousness is the pure aware-ing factor which is infinite. Unlike breaks in thought, space-time etc. there are no breaks in consciousness. It is one infinite whole and everything is encompassed in it including space-time, any other dimensions or universes, thought, emotions, perceptions, actions, all the laws of physics. This is because it is not composed of matter/energy. It is the observer of matter/energy and therefore has to be something other.Matter/energy cannot experience itself. Can a spoon witness a spoon? It is fundamental. Consciousness is God, states Advaita Vedanta. We have to distinguish between Pure Consciousness and Conditioned Consciousness. Self-Absorbed: Pure Consciousness is awareness per se. Consciousness on its own. The aware-ing factor. It has no limitations. It has no boundaries. It is eternal and infinite. It is not aware ‘of’ anything. It is just only awareness. It is not energy/matter. Vedanta declares it as God. It existed before the Big Bang and Multi-Universes and is the common factor in all Universes because it doesn’t acknowledge anything other than itself and is the only non-material aspect in the universe. It is blind to conditioned consciousness. Just as a mirror reflects infinite objects but can't see any of them. When It contacts energy/matter in any form- thought, emotion, perception, impulse, intuition etc. it becomes conditioned Consciousness. Pure Consciousness becomes ‘conscious of’…..thoughts, emotions, intuition, perceptions, sensations etc. Its point of contact in humans is in the electrochemistry in the brain. That’s when Pure Consciousness becomes conditioned. Of course, the conditioning factor and point varies from species to species. Unchanging: This personality, the physical body as well as the mind, whether you take it as an independent entity or the brain, is always in a flux of change. Subatomic particles, atoms, molecules, enter and exit the brain at various frequencies. How can these unequal factors be equal to one and the same ‘I?’ Also, our life, our day, is a cycle of three different states or worlds. The wake-er is not equal to the dreamer, is not equal to the deep sleeper. Yet we claim these three personalities as ‘I.’ The unconscious mind, as in deep sleep and swoon, is the seed of the conscious mind. This is proven by the ballet dancer or the astronaut being the same before and after deep sleep. They don’t change going through this nothingness. That means that during deep sleep (unconscious) they were in their non-manifested or seed state.Consciousness is aware of the ‘nothingness’ of deep-sleep. We report that we had a ‘sound’ or ‘deep’ sleep. Who is aware of the nothingness of deep-sleep? Real: Similarly, it is aware of the dreamer going through the experience of the dream world. The dream world seems as real to the dream personality as the waking world seems to our personality. That is why Vedanta claims, that as we cant prove that the dream state is any more real than the waking state, and we know the dream is merely made of our imagination (thought stuff), it is then logical to presume this world is nothing but a dream. Identical in All: Actually, from Pure Consciousnesses standpoint there is no real contact point between Pure Consciousness and energy-matter, because Pure Consciousness, by definition is Identical in all that experience It. Therefore Fundamental, One, Whole, Infinite, Eternal. Conditioned Consciousness, which witnesses the workings of the mind, just appears to be, like a mirage in a desert or a sound or sight heard or seen by the mentally ill. The world is therefore only an appearance, a dream, and not real. Hindu and Buddhist philosophies call it ‘Maya’ (Illusion). The only reality in this or any universe or before the universes were formed is Pure Consciousness. God. You and I and everyone and everything is, in reality, only that Pure Consciousness. And your physical and mental personality and the world, is a result of Conditioned Consciousness, which is an illusion and a delusion. Being: ‘I’ has to be independent of the matrix of perceptions, emotions, and thoughts. We say ‘I think.’ Then we say ‘I feel.’ Simultaneously, we say ‘I see,’ ‘I hear.’ Now, the thinker is not the feeler, is not the seer, is not the hearer. How can so many unequal factors be equal to one and the same ‘I?’Those who claim that ‘I’ is an amalgam of all these factors should restudy mathematics. Do we have many identities? Even in multiple personalities, the thoughts etc. differ but the experience of awareness/identity remains as one. Unless you believe that a singular entity called ‘I’ is comprised of more than one being, it is impossible to claim that ‘I’ is an amalgam of so many mental, emotional, and perceptive inputs without realizing that pure Consciousness, which absorbs all these exterior energies, is the real ‘I.’ Neutral: The most difficult aspect of Consciousness to appreciate is that it is neutral. It is only the intellect (brain), which is the object of experience, which differentiates, judges.God is neither good nor bad nor does She take sides. She is the silent Witness. He, she, or it, because it is above gender, is the empowering force of nature. Take away conditioned consciousness from a being and it will certainly not be empowered to think, feel, perceive, act. It is the source of all energy.The fountainhead of all energy is within. Consciousness is that which breathes life into the mind and propels the physical body. It is the bio in the biological. Energizer: By extension, It gave vitality and energy for the Big Bang to explode, for electrons and gamma rays to dance, for birds to twit, for Pavarotti to sing. This is because it is fundamental energy and non-material as proved above.It gave power to Christ and Buddha to walk the earth, but it also gave power to Hitler and Genghis Khan. The same power that backs the noblest of deeds backs the most sordid of crimes. It by itself remains neutral. It is like electricity and petrol, they empower but they have no say in the actual working of the gadgets and vehicles. That depends on the quality of the equipment. The Creator and Governor of the Laws of the Universe: It is beyond the realms of time, space, and causation. It is beyond the 4 fields of the Universe. It is beyond energy, force, and matter. The simplest answer is that nobody is quite sure how consciousness works, but that there’s quite a bit of inferential evidence indicating how it is that people (and other animals) are conscious. We cannot be epistemologically certain how consciousness works because of the Hard Problem of Consciousness. This basically states that understanding the physical workings of a thinking system cannot, in principle, tell you why it is conscious because you cannot bridge the gap between the physical processes of a brain and the subjective experience of that brain’s owner. Indeed, the very notion that a brain has an owner illustrates the conundrum. That said, scientists and philosophers have sussed out quite a bit about how consciousness works. To understand how consciousness works, we first have to have a definition of what consciousness is. As suggested by Thomas Nagel in his seminal paper, What is it Like to Be a Bat?, a conscious entity is one that experiences subjective states - one that it is “like something” to be. That is, it’s like something to be conscious and like nothing to lack consciousness. Thus, it’s like something to be a whale or a gibbon, as these are conscious creatures, but not like anything to be a bowl of petunias or a rock, since these are incapable of intelligible experience. While consciousness generally involves an awareness of the surrounding world, this need not be the case - in altered states of consciousness, such as an immersive psychedelic experience or a vivid dream, one’s subjective experiences might have little to do with happenings in the world. In summary, consciousness is the presence of a subject, any subject, to experience things. By all accounts, consciousness appears to be generated by our brains. While many people claim to have had out-of-body and other unexplainable experiences that would give us cause to question (for instance, neurosurgeon Eben Alexander, who wrote a book on his near-death experience), these experiences are not generally convincing because there are no confirmed examples of conscious experience in the absence of concomitant brain activity (see Michael Shermer’s rebuttal to Alexander). The brain is crucial - the destruction of brain tissue can lead to impairments in consciousness or even a persistent vegetative state that cannot be overcome. The most important brain area for the generation of consciousness is the cerebral cortex, the wrinkly envelope of brain tissue that covers the outside of your brain. There’s no singular area in the cortex responsible for consciousness. Indeed, it is the action and interaction of many cortical areas that’s thought to be responsible. This is why epileptic patients often lose consciousness during seizures, even though their brains are exceptionally active, and why you go to sleep at night. The cerebral cortex requires tonic (steady) activation to maintain consciousness. This is provided by a deep brain structure called the reticular formation. The reticular formation projects throughout the brain, including to the cortex, where it provides excitatory input in the form of the neurotransmitters, glutamate, acetylcholine, and histamine. This is why antihistamines that cross the blood-brain barrier make you sleepy, and why the destruction of these activating centers generally leads to an irreversible coma state. Another important brain area for the generation of consciousness is the claustrum, a small tissue layer beneath parts of the cortex. Research by various groups has implicated the claustrum in coordinating communications to and within the cortex. Researchers lead by Mohamad Koubeissi at George Washington University found that disrupting this communication via electrical stimulation would reversibly impair consciousness. This is despite the fact that the claustrum itself doesn’t appear to have a crucial role for sensory, memory, or motor processing. The importance of tonic activity (via the reticular formation) and synchronicity (via the claustrum) provides valuable clues about how consciousness may come about. One explanation of recent interest is the self-organizing principles of neural networks and a phenomenon called self-organized criticality. According to this theory, brain centers rest in a default “noisy” state that is somewhat disorganized. This is a sort of stand-by state for initiating decisions, actions, etc. The nature of these brain centers is such that when they receive enough activating input, they will change phases and lock into a different, more syncronized firing pattern. Any given brain network can have many different firing patterns and modes of synchronization. The disruption of these organizing processes explains why seizures and claustrum insterference can cause a loss of consciousness, and our sense of consciousness may itself arise out of the interacting synchronization and desynchronization of thousands of sub-networks within the brain. My suspicion is that our sense of subjective experience represents the resolution of indeterminate “noisy” states of brain activity into discrete, patterned states as we experience things - that is, our sense of experience relies upon active transition of complex brain states in and out of different modes of activity. But this is still very much a theoretical science and, as I admitted at the beginning of this post, nobody really knows. At least not yet.

At any one moment humans are experiencing color, sound, shapes, textures, depth, smell, and emotional cues related to mental health, social status, personal memory, and cultural identity. These various facets of consciousness are wired together through neural networking and synaptic memory and fed into the executive functions of the forebrain. But this model is only valid when you are awake. When you are sleeping consciousness is even more fragmented into deep memory consolidation and perception is limited to very brief snapshots where visual memory is stimulated.

Giancarlo Frigato, Degree in Biology, University of Ferrara (1984) Giancarlo Frigato, Degree in Biology, University of Ferrara (1984) In recent studies, through functional magnetic resonance, Dehaene, Tononi and other neuroscientists have identified the brain areas that are active only during conscious perception but not in simple unconscious perception. Other studies on "hemineglect" highlight the areas of the brain whose injury causes the loss of Consciousness but does not prevent the unconscious perception. These researches have as a result that specific areas of the Cerebral Cortex are the neural correlates of Consciousness. Instead, for example, the removal of the cerebellum damaged by trauma does not prevent the explication of Consciousness. The injury of the brain stem causes the loss of Consciousness but also prevents unconscious perception. Consciousness ensures that within the vast unconscious perception, information selected in a utilitarian way is quickly memorized. Such information, once present in the Memory, may be producing mental images that alone or together with conscious images from the external environment are used to reason (and to communicate with other subjects in the case of Man or the apes). Oakley and Halligan (2017) based on studies about hypnosis (eg, Schlegel et al., 2015, Lush et al., 2017), the divided brain (Gazzaniga, 1988), decision making (Libet et al., 1983 ) and neglect (eg, Driver and Mattingley, 1998; Frigato, 2014), have come to the conclusion that brain operations responsible for all our mental activities take place at the unconscious level. Activities that include perceptions, actions and emotions, but also reasoning, self-control and sense of self. Oakley and Halligan do not use the generic concept of "Consciousness", but they operate the very useful distinction between Personal Narrative (contents of Consciousness) and Personal Awareness (experience of Consciousness) emphasizing how the latter constantly accompany the first in parallel, without minimally influencing the mechanisms responsible for our mental abilities. On the other hand, the Personal Narrative "serves the powerful evolutionary function of enabling individuals to communicate (external broadcast) the contents of internal broadcasting" and its contents are deposited in the higher level Memoirs: Semantic, Episodic and Autobiographical. Reading this article helped me a lot in revisiting the theoretical work I have undertaken to try to identify the neural correlates of consciousness (Frigato, 2014). Something I haven't done in my analysis was making the distinction between Personal Narrative and Personal Awareness. Another distinction that can be made is that between simple automatic unconscious mechanisms and complex unconscious mechanisms (e.g., Gazzaniga, 1988; Moscovictch and Umiltà, 1991; Frigato, 2014). The first are not accompanied by the Personal Narrative and therefore not even by Personal Awareness, the latter instead yes. An example of automatic mechanism is to drive along a road well known to us, perhaps even overtaking, stopping at traffic lights, etc., and realizing only after a certain time, to have passed through it without remembering that we did it. There are therefore unconscious automatic behaviors which we cannot refer about and that we cannot memorize in the 3 higher level Memoirs. Instead the most important and complex unconscious experiences, being able to give rise to the Personal Narrative, can be deposited in the 3 Memoirs which are the source of mental images. In my opinion (Frigato, 2014) the images of the external environment and the mental images present in the Personal Narrative are used not only to exchange information with our neighbors (Oakley and Halligan, 2017), but also to be able to learn in a manner complex through reasoning. Therefore the Personal Narrative not only provides the great evolutionary advantage of being able to communicate with others, but also gives reasoning ability. It can therefore be assumed that up to fish and amphibians there are only automatic learning and memory mechanisms and, starting from the reptiles, a minimum capacity of reasoning appeared, which evolved in birds and mammals to reach the highest levels of efficiency in man (Bitermann and Mackintosh, 1969; Denton,2006). Through a review of the literature related to neglect, I hypothesized (Frigato, 2014) that the mechanism that produces the Personal Narrative is made of 8 + 8 large areas specularly present in the two cerebral hemispheres. They all work simultaneously in parallel as "points of convergence" between the 3 higher level Memories and other 8 + 8 brain areas specialized in perception and movement. The latter are responsible respectively for the recognition of a specific object, its position in space, the emotions it produces, the position of the body with respect to the object itself, the state of the body at the moment of perception and the 3 motor potentials related to that object. In the specific case of visual Personal Narrative (Frigato, 2014), the medial-superior temporal lobe work as a “point of convergence” and keep simultaneously active both the occipital and inferior temporal cortices responsible for visual perception and the precuneus-posterior cingulate, the seat of 3 Superior Memories. So, to obtain the Personal Narrative of external perception, in addition to the image that comes from the environment, the mirror memory corresponding to that image should be simultaneously activated and superimposed. Conversely when the Personal Narrative is arrived at through visual mental images that come from memory, the superior-medial temporal lobe simultaneously maintains active the neurons in the sensorial cortices (occipital and inferior temporal), which have been the source of external visual perception in the corresponding previous experiences. There would therefore be a continuous feedback and alternation between activation of the neurons responsible for perception and those responsible for memory. With mental images there would obviously be a predominance of precuneus memory, while during external perception the prevailing activities would be in the sensory cortices (Ganis et al., 2004; Mechelli et al., 2004). As already highlighted, Oakley and Halligan operate the very useful distinction between Personal Narrative and Personal Awareness. They say that after trying to explain the Personal Narrative, the "New Hard Problem" still remains to solve the identification of the neural mechanisms of Personal Awareness: "How and why do neurophysiological activities produce the "experience of consciousness"?"; (Chalmers, 1996). My theoretical work (Frigato, 2014) tries to explain the feeling of Personal Awareness with the fact that, in the production of Personal Narrative, are involved the 8 + 8 "points of convergence", the 3 Memories, and 8 + 8 sensory and motor areas. All these areas acting simultaneously and in parallel could create a wide "psychophysical activation" such as to produce Personal Awareness. For example, the images coming from the external environment or the mental images of a red sunset, of a green landscape, of human faces and so on, would create practically infinite different combinations of psychophysical sensations. Such as to explain how Personal Awareness varies at any moment and is absolutely private and personal. The presence of these almost infinite combinations would also explain why the problem of Personal Awareness appears as a "Hard Problem": the human brain usually reasons on at most 3-4 spatio-temporal dimensions and therefore finds hard to explain rationally such large and complicated combinations. Not a whole lot of progress has been made on this question scientifically. There are really two separate questions here (which may be related, of course). One is the "easy" question of how the brain produces behaviour and processes information. The other is the "hard" question of why we experience emotion along with this processing. Some argue that the second question doesn't really need answering at all and isn't puzzling; others (like me) argue that it is an important question. Of those who think it's important and valid, many think the answer has something to do with the complexity of the brain. Others think it may point to some fundamental misunderstanding about the nature of physical matter. There is widespread disagreement on even basic questions in this field, like whether a digital computer could experience emotion, whether ants or unborn humans experience emotion, and whether or not emotion can only be generated by the type of stuff the brain is made of, or could be generated by any suitable system. The trend in scientific opinion has generally shifted towards regarding consciousness as an emergent property of matter, but there is currently no real proof for any of many rival hypotheses.

On any philosophical and scientific level, we have no idea. There are good philosophical reasons to believe that the mind and brain are separate (not in the Cartesian "ghost in the machine" sense), yet interacting entities. In terms of the scientific realm, we have a long way to go. It may be that consciousness is emergent, and therefore not really ontologically reducible.  Therefore, would we really be asking the right question if we ask "How does human consciousness work?"
